thread.title: Revealed: The North East MP who claimed the most expenses this year

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Revealed: The North East MP who claimed the most expenses this year
text:

The North East MPs with the highest expenses claims have been revealed.
Paul Williams, Labour MP for Stockton South, has claimed £44,938 so far this year.
It makes him far and away the most expensive MP in the North East.
He said his costs were higher than those of other MPs partly because he was elected for the first time in the 2017 general election, taking a Conservative-held seat.
He said: “These are the costs of train travel to and from London, rent of a flat in London, setting up an office in my constituency and running that office. My costs for this period are higher than most other MPs because of the £6,000 start-up supplement and because of my family caring responsibilities.” Stockton South MP Paul Williams (Image: Paul Williams)
Much of the money, £10,833 of the amount claimed, was for accommodation.
Some £3,857 was for business rates and £528 was spent on renting a constituency office.
Mr Williams spent £2,247 on new computer equipment, and £392 went on food and drink for staff.
In second place was Grahame Morris, Labour MP for Easington, who so far this year has claimed £26,271.
That included 8,559 for accommodation and £8,823 on renting a constituency office.
There was also £1,907 was for new computer equipment, and £178 went on business cards.
MPs are allowed to claim expenses to help them pay the costs of doing their job.
That includes staying overnight in London when the House of Commons is sitting, and travelling to the capital from their constituencies on a regular basis.
Many MPs also have offices in their constituencies, designed to make it easy for constituents to find them, and have to pay rent for that. Read More Anne-Marie Trevelyan accused of "abandoning" constituency as she quits Government post over Brexit
But different MPs approach their jobs in different ways. Some see their role as offering help and advice directly to their constituents, and might spend money on a high-profile office on a high street.
Others believe their focus should be firmly on representing constituents in the House of Commons, and may have lower costs in their constituency but spend more time in London.
MPs have an annual salary of £77,379, and can earn more if they have a Government role or chair a committee.
However, expenses are not a supplement to their salary and MPs get no direct benefit from them.
The system went through radical reforms following the expenses scandal in 2009, when it was discovered that one MP had claimed £1,645 for a duck shelter in his pond.
MPs were able to buy second homes in London and claim for the cost of the mortgage, potentially giving them a valuable property at taxpayers’ expense. This system has been abolished.
Our analysis found that Hexham MP Guy Opperman claimed £25,500 so far this year, Middlesbrough MP Andy McDonald claimed £25,394, and Simon Clarke, MP for Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland, claimed £23,777. Read More
The average cost of expenses claimed so far this year is £16,964 per MP.
That makes a total £11m claimed by all MPs since January.
Only eight of the claiming MPs in the North East were below average, but this could be because they have to travel further to London than others. Who spent what?
Paul Williams, Stockton South, £44,938
Grahame Morris, Easington, £26,271
